Version 3.0 and 3.10 CORE rules.Textual statement of rule: Class relationships must conform with the USDM schema based on the API specification.
Data types of attributes (string, number, boolean) must conform with the USDM schema based on the API specification.
Attributes must be included as defined in the USDM schema based on the API specification (i.e., all required properties are present and no additional attributes are present).
Cardinalities must be as defined in the USDM schema based on the API specification (i.e., required properties have at least one value and single-value properties are not lists).
Within a study version, all id values must be unique.
The names of all child instances of the same parent class must be unique.
All abbreviations defined for a study version must be unique.
The long names for all abbreviations defined for a study version are expected to be unique.
The same Biomedical Concept Category must not be referenced more than once from the same activity.
Each specified biomedical concept category is expected to be referenced by an activity.
Each specified biomedical concept surrogate is expected to be referenced by an activity.
Each specified biomedical concept is expected to be referenced by an activity.
An activity with children must not refer to a timeline, procedure, biomedical concept, biomedical concept category or biomedical concept surrogate.
Each specified procedure is expected to be referenced by an activity.
An activity is expected to refer to at least one procedure, biomedical concept, biomedical concept category or biomedical concept surrogate.
The ordering of activities (using the previous and next attributes) must include the parents (e.g. activities refering to children) preceding their children.
An activity must only reference activities that are specified within the same study design.
An activity must only reference timelines that are specified within the same study design.
If a biomedical concept is referenced from an activity then it is not expected to be referenced as well by a biomedical concept category that is referenced from the same activity.
To ensure consistent ordering, when both previous and next attributes are available within an entity the previous id value must match the next id value of the referred instance.
To ensure consistent ordering, the same instance must not be referenced more than once as previous or next.
At least one attribute must be specified for an address.
At least one attribute must be specified for an address.

An administrable dose form must be specfied according to the extensible Pharmaceutical Dosage Form (C66726) SDTM codelist (e.g. an entry with a code or decode used from the codelist should be consistent with the full entry in the codelist).
An administrable product sourcing must be specified using the sourcing (Cxxx) DDF codelist.

An administrable product property type must be specified according to the extensible administrable property type (Cxxxx) DDF codelist (e.g. an entry with a code or decode used from the codelist should be consistent with the full entry in the codelist).
An administrable product must not be referenced as both the administrable product for an administration and the embedded product of a medical device that is referenced by the same administration.
If a dose is specified then a corresponding frequency must also be specified.
If a dose is specified, then a corresponding administrable product must also be specified either directly or embedded in the medical device and vice versa.
If an administration's dose is specified then a corresponding route is expected and vice versa.

An administration's frequency must be specfied according to the extensible Frequency (C71113) SDTM codelist (e.g. an entry with a code or decode used from the codelist should be consistent with the full entry in the codelist).

An administration's route must be specfied according to the extensible Route of Administration Response (C66729) SDTM codelist (e.g. an entry with a code or decode used from the codelist should be consistent with the full entry in the codelist).
If duration will vary (attribute durationWillVary is True) then a reason (attribute reasonDurationWillVary) must be given and vice versa.
If the duration of an administration will vary, a quantity is not expected for the administration duration and vice versa.
Sourcing must not be defined for an administrable product which is only referenced as an embedded product for a medical device.

An agent administration's frequency must be specified according to the extensible Frequency (C71113) SDTM codelist (e.g. an entry with a code or decode used from the codelist should be consistent with the full entry in the codelist).

An agent administration's route must be specified according to the extensible Route of Administration Response (C66729) SDTM codelist (e.g. an entry with a code or decode used from the codelist should be consistent with the full entry in the codelist).
All standard code aliases referenced by an instance of the alias code class must be unique.
A standard code alias is not expected to be equal to the standard code (e.g. no equal code or decode for the same coding system version is expected).
If a synonym is specified then it is not expected to be equal to the name of the biomedical concept (case insensitive).
A biomedical concept category is expected to have at least a member or a child.
An instance of a class must not reference itself as one of its own children.
If a biomedical concept property is required then it must also be enabled, while if it is not enabled then it must not be required.
If a biospecimen retention indicates that a type of biospecimen is retained, then there must be an indication of whether the type of biospecimen includes DNA.
Within a code system and corresponding version, a one-to-one relationship between code and decode is expected.
Only one version of any code system is expected to be used within a study version.
For CDISC codelist references (where the code system is 'http://www.cdisc.org'), the code system version must be a valid CDISC terminology release date in ISO 8601 date format.
A specified condition for assessments must apply to at least to a procedure, biomedical concept, biomedical concept surrogate, biomedical concept category or a whole activity.

When a condition applies to a procedure, activity, biomedical concept, biomedical concept category, or biomedical concept surrogate then an instance must be available in the corresponding class with the specified id.
If specified, the context of a condition must point to a valid instance in the activity or scheduled activity instance class.
The target for a condition must not be equal to its parent.
There must be a one-to-one relationship between referenced section number and title within a study amendment.
An eligibility criterion's category must be specified using the Category of Inclusion/Exclusion (C66797) SDTM codelist.

When included in text, references to items specified in the dictionary must be specified in the correct format. They must start with <usdm:tag, end with either '/>'', and must contain name="parametername" (where "parametername"  contain only letters, numbers or underscores).
Any parameter name referenced in a tag in the text should be specified in the data dictionary parameter maps.
Syntax template text is expected to be HTML formatted.
Within an encounter there must be no duplicate contact modes.

An encounter's contact modes must be specified according to the Mode of Subject Contact (C171445) SDTM codelist (e.g. an entry with a code or decode used from the codelist should be consistent with the full entry in the codelist).
Within an encounter there must be no duplicate environmental settings.

An encounter's environmental setting must be specified according to the extensible Environmental Setting (C127262) SDTM codelist (e.g. an entry with a code or decode used from the codelist should be consistent with the full entry in the codelist).
Within an encounter, if more environmental settings are defined, they must be distinct.

An encounter's environmental setting must be specified according to the extensible Environmental Setting (C127262) SDTM codelist (e.g. an entry with a code or decode used from the codelist should be consistent with the full entry in the codelist).
Encounter ordering using previous and next attributes is expected to be consistent with the order of corresponding scheduled activity instances according to their specified default conditions.
An encounter must only reference encounters that are specified within the same study design.
An encounter must only be scheduled at a timing that is defined within the same study design as the encounter.

An encounter type must be specified according to the extensible encounter type (C188728) DDF codelist (e.g. an entry with a code or decode used from the codelist should be consistent with the full entry in the codelist).
Within a study design, there must be at least one endpoint with level primary.
All primary endpoints must be referenced by a primary objective.
An endpoint level must be specified using the endpoint level (C188726) DDF codelist.

If geographic scope type is global then no codes are expected to specify the specific area within scope while if it is not global then at least one code is expected to specify the specific area within scope.
A study geographic scope type must be specified using the geographic scope type (C207412) DDF codelist.
If geographic scope type is global then there must be only one geographic scope specified.

A governance date type must be specified according to the extensible governance date type (C207413) DDF codelist (e.g. an entry with a code or decode used from the codelist should be consistent with the full entry in the codelist).
Within an indication, if more indication codes are defined, they must be distinct.

A study design's blinding schema must be specified according to the extensible Trial Blinding Schema Response (C66735) SDTM codelist (e.g. an entry with a code or decode used from the codelist should be consistent with the full entry in the codelist).

An interventional study design's intent types must be specified according to the extensible Trial Intent Type Response (C66736) SDTM codelist (e.g. an entry with a code or decode used from the codelist should be consistent with the full entry in the codelist).
Within a study design, if more intent types are defined, they must be distinct.
If the intervention model indicates a single group design then only one intervention is expected. In all other cases more interventions are expected.

A study design's intervention model must be specified according to the extensible Intervention Model Response (C99076) SDTM codelist (e.g. an entry with a code or decode used from the codelist should be consistent with the full entry in the codelist).
An interventional study must be specified using the InterventionalStudyDesign class.

An interventional study design's sub types must be specified according to the extensible Trial Type Response (C66739) SDTM codelist (e.g. an entry with a code or decode used from the codelist should be consistent with the full entry in the codelist).

A study design's characteristics must be specified according to the study design characteristics (C207416) DDF codelist (e.g. an entry with a code or decode used from the codelist should be consistent with the full entry in the codelist).
Within a study design, if more characteristics are defined, they must be distinct.
Within a study design, if more sub types are defined, they must be distinct.
Within a study design, if more therapeutic areas are defined, they must be distinct.

A masking role must be specified according to the extensible masking role (C207414) DDF codelist (e.g. an entry with a code or decode used from the codelist should be consistent with the full entry in the codelist).
A medical device sourcing must be specified using the sourcing (Cxxx) DDF codelist.

A medical device identifier type must be specified according to the extensible medical device identifier type (Cxxx) DDF codelist (e.g. an entry with a code or decode used from the codelist should be consistent with the full entry in the codelist).
Narrative content is expected to point to a child and/or to a content item text.
A piece of narrative content must only reference narrative content items that have been defined within the study version as the narrative content.
Narrative content must only reference narrative content that is specified within the same study definition document version.
Within a document version, the specified section numbers for narrative content must be unique.
If a section number is to be displayed then a number must be specified and vice versa.
If a section title is to be displayed then a title must be specified and vice versa.

When included in text, references to items stored elsewhere in the data model must be specified in the correct format. They must start with '<usdm:ref', end with either '/>' or '></usdm:ref>', and must contain 'klass="klassName"',  'id="idValue"', and 'attribute="attributeName"/>' in any order (where "klassName" and "attributeName" contain only letters in upper or lower case).
Referenced items in the narrative content must be available elsewhere in the data model.
Narrative content text is expected to be HTML formatted.

When included in text, references to items stored elsewhere in the data model must be specified in the correct format. They must start with '<usdm:ref', end with either '/>' or '></usdm:ref>', and must contain 'klass="KlassName"',  'id="idValue"', and 'attribute="attributeName"/>' in any order (where "ClassName" and "attributeName" contain only letters in upper or lower case).
Narrative content item text is expected to be HTML formatted.
Within a study design there must be exactly one objective with level 'Primary Objective'.
An objective level must be specified using the objective level (C188725) DDF codelist.

A study design's observational model must be specified according to the extensible Observational Study Model (C127259) SDTM codelist (e.g. an entry with a code or decode used from the codelist should be consistent with the full entry in the codelist).

An observational study design's sampling method must be specified according to the extensible Observational Study Sampling Method (C127260) SDTM codelist (e.g. an entry with a code or decode used from the codelist should be consistent with the full entry in the codelist).
An observational study (including patient registries) is expected to have a study phase decode value of "NOT APPLICABLE".
An observational study (including patient registries) must be specified using the ObservationalStudyDesign class.

A observational study design's sub types must be specified according to the (Cxxxx) DDF codelist (e.g. an entry with a code or decode used from the codelist should be consistent with the full entry in the codelist).

An observational study design's time perspective must be specified according to the extensible Observational Study Time Perspective (C127261) SDTM codelist (e.g. an entry with a code or decode used from the codelist should be consistent with the full entry in the codelist).
A study definition document version must not be referenced more than once by the same study design.

A study design's study phase must be specified according to the extensible Trial Phase Response (C66737) SDTM codelist (e.g. an entry with a code or decode used from the codelist should be consistent with the full entry in the codelist).
A study design's study type must be specified using the Study Type Response (C99077) SDTM codelist.

An organization type must be specified according to the extensible organization type (C188724) DDF codelist (e.g. an entry with a code or decode used from the codelist should be consistent with the full entry in the codelist).

An organization type must be specified according to the extensible organization type (C188724) DDF codelist (e.g. an entry with a code or decode used from the codelist should be consistent with the full entry in the codelist).
Referenced items in a parameter map must be available elsewhere in the data model.

References must be a fixed value or a reference to items stored elsewhere in the data model which must be specified in the correct format. They must start with '<usdm:ref', end with either '/>' or '></usdm:ref>', and must contain 'klass="klassName"', 'id="idValue"', and 'attribute="attributeName"/>' in any order (where "klassName" and "attributeName" contain only letters in upper or lower case).
A procedure must only reference a study intervention that is defined within the same study design as the activity within which the procedure is defined.
Within a study design, if study type is Interventional then at least one intervention is expected to be referenced from a procedure.
A product organization role is expected to apply to at least one medical device or administrable product.
If 'appliesTo' is specified for a product organization role, then the product organization role must only apply to medical devices or administrable products.
The range specified for a planned age is not expected to be approximate.
For a specified range at least a minimum or maximum value is expected.
The minimum value of a range must be less than or equal to the maximum value of the range.
A unit must be coded according to the extensible unit (C71620) SDTM codelist (e.g. an entry with a code or decode used from the codelist should be consistent with the full entry in the codelist).

A reference identifier type must be specified according to the extensible reference identifier type (Cxxx) DDF codelist  (e.g. an entry with a code or decode used from the codelist should be consistent with the full entry in the codelist).
A scheduled activity instance must only reference an encounter that is defined within the same study design as the scheduled activity instance.
All epochs are expected to be referred to from a scheduled Activity Instance.
All scheduled activity instances are expected to refer to an epoch.
A scheduled activity instance must not point (via the "timeline" relationship) to the timeline in which it is specified.
A scheduled activity instance must only have a sub-timeline that is defined within the same study design as the scheduled activity instance.
At least one scheduled activity instance within a timeline must point to a timeline exit.
A scheduled activity instance must only reference a timeline exit that is defined within the same schedule timeline as the scheduled activity instance.
A scheduled activity instance must refer to either a default condition or a timeline exit, but not both.
A scheduled activity/decision instance must not refer to itself as its default condition.
A scheduled activity/decision instance must only reference an epoch that is defined within the same study design as the scheduled activity/decision instance.
A scheduled decision instance must refer to a default condition.
A scheduled decision instance is expected to refer to a default condition.
A scheduled decision instance is not expected to have a sub-timeline.
A scheduled decision instance is not expected to refer to a timeline exit.
There must be at least one exit defined for each timeline (i.e., at least one instance of StudyTimelineExit linked via the 'exits' relationship).
Within a study design, there must be exactly one scheduled timeline which identifies as the main Timeline.
A unit must be specified for every strength denominator and numerator

An study impact type must be specified according to the extensible study amendment impact type (Cxxxx) DDF codelist (e.g. an entry with a code or decode used from the codelist should be consistent with the full entry in the codelist).
A study amendment reason must be coded using the study amendment reason (C207415) DDF codelist.
If the reason for a study amendment is 'Other' then this must be specified (attribute reasonOther must be completed)

A study arm data origin type must be specified according to the extensible data origin type (C188727) DDF codelist (e.g. an entry with a code or decode used from the codelist should be consistent with the full entry in the codelist).
A study arm must only reference populations that are defined within the same study design as the study arm.
A study arm must only reference study populations or cohorts that are defined within the same study design as the study arm.
A study cell must only reference an arm that is defined within the same study design as the study cell.
Each StudyArm must have one StudyCell for each StudyEpoch.
Each combination of arm and epoch must occur no more than once within a study design.
Each study element must be referenced by at least one study cell.
A study cell must only reference elements that are defined within the same study design as the study cell.
A study cell must refer to at least one element.
A study cell must only reference an epoch that is defined within the same study design as the study cell.

A study definition document type must be specifed according to the extensible XXX (Cnnn) DDF codelist (e.g. an entry with a code or decode used from the codelist should be consistent with the full entry in the codelist).
Date values associated to a study protocol document version must be unique regarding the combination of type and geographic scopes of the date.
Within a study protocol document version, if a date of a specific type exists with a global geographic scope then no other dates are expected with the same type.
A study definition document version's status must be specifed using the status Value Set Terminology (C188723) DDF codelist.

A study design's blinding schema must be specified according to the extensible Trial Blinding Schema Response (C66735) SDTM codelist (e.g. an entry with a code or decode used from the codelist should be consistent with the full entry in the codelist).

A study design's characteristics must be specified according to the Study design characteristics (C207416) DDF codelist (e.g. an entry with a code or decode used from the codelist should be consistent with the full entry in the codelist).
Within a study design, if more characteristics are defined, they must be distinct.

A study design's intervention model must be specified according to the extensible Intervention Model Response (C99076) SDTM codelist (e.g. an entry with a code or decode used from the codelist should be consistent with the full entry in the codelist).
If the intervention model indicates a single group design then only one intervention is expected. In all other cases more interventions are expected.
Within a study design, if more therapeutic areas are defined, they must be distinct.

A study design's trial intent types must be specified according to the extensible Trial Intent Type Response (C66736) SDTM codelist (e.g. an entry with a code or decode used from the codelist should be consistent with the full entry in the codelist).
Within a study design, if more trial intent types are defined, they must be distinct.

A study design's trial types must be specified according to the extensible Trial Type Response (C66739) SDTM codelist (e.g. an entry with a code or decode used from the codelist should be consistent with the full entry in the codelist).
Within a study design, if more trial types are defined, they must be distinct.
Within a study design, there must be at least 1 eligibility criterion that is referenced by either a study population or a cohort.
Within a study design, the planned age range must be specified either in the study population or in all cohorts.
The unit of a planned age is expected to be specified using terms from the Age Unit (C66781) SDTM codelist.
Within a study design, if a planned completion number is defined, it must be specified either in the study population or in all cohorts.
Within a study design, if a planned enrollment number is defined, it must be specified either in the study population or in all cohorts.
A unit must not be specified for a planned enrollment number or a planned completion number.
Within a study design, the planned sex must be specified either in the study population or in all cohorts.
A planned sex must be specified using the Sex of Participants (C66732) SDTM codelist.
A planned sex must ether include a single entry of male or female or both female and male as entries.
A study element must only reference study interventions that are defined within the same study design as the study element.
If a transition start rule is defined then an end rule is expected and vice versa.
Epoch ordering using previous and next attributes is expected to be consistent with the order of corresponding scheduled activity instances according to their specified default conditions.
An epoch must only reference epochs that are specified within the same study design.
An instance of a class must not refer to itself as its next instance.
An instance of a class must not refer to itself as its previous instance.
Version 3.0 and 3.10 CORE rules.Entity(ies) to which the rule applies: StudyEpoch, Encounter, Activity, NarrativeContent, EligibilityCriterion, StudyAmendment

Version 3.0 and 3.10 CORE rules.Textual statement of rule: There must be exactly one sponsor study identifier (i.e., a study identifier whose scope is an organization that is identified as the organization for the sponsor study role).
An identified organization is not expected to have more than 1 identifier for the study.
Every identifier must be unique within the scope of an identified organization.
Every study version must have exactly one study identifier with an identifier scope that references a clinical study sponsor organization.
An identified organization is not expected to have more than one identifier for the study.
Every identifier must be unique within the scope of an identified organization.
Within a study intervention, if more intervention codes are defined, they must be distinct.
A study intervention's product designation must be specified using the product designation (C207418) DDF codelist.
An administrable product's product designation must be specified using the product designation (C207418) DDF codelist.
A study intervention's role must be specified using the study intervention role (C207417) DDF codelist.
A study intervention's type must be specified using the Intervention Type Response (C99078) SDTM codelist.
Date values associated to a study protocol document version must be unique regarding the combination of type and geographic scopes of the date.
Within a study protocol document version, if a date of a specific type exists with a global geographic scope then no other dates are expected with the same type.
A study protocol document version's protocol status must be specified using the Protocol Status Value Set Terminology (C188723) DDF codelist.
Every study role must apply to either a study version or at least one study design, but not both.
The sponsor study role must be applicable to a study version.
A study role must not reference both assigned persons and organizations.
There must be exactly one study role with a code of sponsor.
A masking is not expected to be defined for any study role in a study design with an open label blinding schema.
A masking is expected to be defined for at least two study roles in a study design with a double blind blinding schema.
A masking is expected to be defined for at least one study role in a study design with a blinding schema that is not open label or double blind.
The sponsor study role must point to exactly one organization.
A study title type must be specified using the study title type (C207419) DDF codelist.
Within a study version, if more than 1 business therapeutic area is defined then they must be distinct.
Each defined elibility criterion must be used by at least one study population or cohort.
An eligility criterion must not be referenced by both a study design population and any of the cohorts of the same study design population.
Date values associated to a study version must be unique regarding the combination of type and geographic scopes of the date.
Within a study version, if a date of a specific type exists with a global geographic scope then no other dates are expected with the same type.
A study definition document version must not be referenced more than once by the same study version.

A study version's study phase must be specified according to the extensible Trial Phase Response (C66737) SDTM codelist (e.g. an entry with a code or decode used from the codelist should be consistent with the full entry in the codelist).
A study version's study type must be specified using the Study Type Response (C99077) SDTM codelist.
Within a study version, there must be no more than one title of each type.
Every study version must have a title of type "Official Study Title".
Each study definition document version is expected to be referenced by either a study version or a study design.
Each study enrollment must apply to either a geographic scope, a study site, or a study cohort.
Within subject enrollment, the quantity must be a number or a percentage (i.e. the unit must be empty or %).
A referenced substance must not have any references itself.
Anchor timings (e.g. type is "Fixed Reference") must be related to a scheduled activity instance via a relativeFromScheduledInstance relationship.
A timing must only be specified as being relative to/from a scheduled activity/decision instance that is defined within the same timeline as the timing.
If timing type is "Fixed Reference" then the corresponding attribute relativeToFrom must be filled with "Start to Start".
A timing's relative to/from property must be specified using the Timing Relative To From Value Set Terminology (C201265) SDTM codelist.

If timing type is "Fixed Reference" then it must point to only one scheduled instance (e.g. attribute relativeToScheduledInstance must be equal to relativeFromScheduledInstance or it must be missing).

If timing type is not "Fixed Reference" then it must point to two scheduled instances (e.g. the relativeFromScheduledInstance and relativeToScheduledInstance attributes must not be missing and must not be equal to each other).
Each schedule timeline must contain at least one anchor (fixed time) - i.e., at least one scheduled activity instance that is referenced by a Fixed Reference timing.
A timing's type must be specified using the Timing Type Value Set Terminology (C201264) DDF codelist.
The value for each timing must be a non-negative duration specified in ISO 8601 format.
Timing windows must be fully defined, if one of the window attributes (i.e., window label, window lower, and window upper) is defined then all must be specified.
A window must not be defined for an anchor timing (i.e., type is "Fixed Reference").
When specified, the lower limit of a timing window must be a non-negative duration in ISO 8601 format.
When specified, the upper limit of a timing window must be a non-negative duration in ISO 8601 format.
